Quadratic Functions Practice

Practice problems for understanding quadratic functions and their properties.

Exercise 1: Vertex Form Conversion

Convert each quadratic function to vertex form and identify the vertex.

1.1 Standard to Vertex Form

Function: f(x)=x2+6x+5f(x) = x^2 + 6x + 5f(x)=x2+6x+5

Vertex form:








Complete the square: x2+6x+5=(x2+6x+9)−9+5=(x+3)2−4x^2 + 6x + 5 = (x^2 + 6x + 9) - 9 + 5 = (x + 3)^2 - 4x2+6x+5=(x2+6x+9)−9+5=(x+3)2−4


Vertex coordinates:





1.2 Standard to Vertex Form

Function: f(x)=2x2−8x+3f(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 3f(x)=2x2−8x+3

Vertex form:








Factor out 2 first: 2(x2−4x)+3=2(x2−4x+4)−8+3=2(x−2)2−52(x^2 - 4x) + 3 = 2(x^2 - 4x + 4) - 8 + 3 = 2(x - 2)^2 - 52(x2−4x)+3=2(x2−4x+4)−8+3=2(x−2)2−5


Vertex coordinates:

Exercise 3: Applications

3.1 Projectile Motion

A ball is thrown upward from a height of 6 feet. Its height hhh (in feet) after ttt seconds is given by:

h(t)=−16t2+32t+6h(t) = -16t^2 + 32t + 6h(t)=−16t2+32t+6
